subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] bear beer
msgSnippet: ... Well, it s a full merger of two lexical sets, because words with and without R are always in different lexical sets.  Many dialects merge things like PALM
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> So yes, it does only happen with R. So I guess it's not a full merger,

Well, it's a full merger of two lexical sets, because words with and
without R are always in different lexical sets. Many dialects merge
things like PALM = START, but these are never merged in QS.

> I'm am going to write a document on mergers, explaining what they are,
> and then try to group sets, rank the severity the problem the merger
> presents, possible solutions, and example words. In truth, I don't know
> a lot of different sets, but rather than my making another chart, I
> think a merger document might be more useful to tackle the problem in a
> more concrete way. I have been busy today (you can see why in my next
> post), so I haven't gotten around to it.

Work your way through
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonological_history_of_English_vowels and
the pages linked from it (labeled "Main article") and you'll know all
there is to be knowed about the subject.

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
Objective consideration of contemporary phenomena compel the conclusion
that optimum or inadequate performance in the trend of competitive
activities exhibits no tendency to be commensurate with innate capacity,
but that a considerable element of the unpredictable must invariably be
taken into account. --Ecclesiastes 9:11, Orwell/Brown version
